title: The Architects of History
author: Steve Lyons
filename: 132 - The Architects of History - Steve Lyons_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1. HANGAR
FX: LARGE, ECHO-Y SPACE. TARDIS BEGINS TO MATERIALISE
Warning. Incursion detected in Hangar Fourteen. End warning.
(FX: SAM AND RACHEL RUN TOWARDS US, FOOTSTEPS RINGING ON STONE, STOP)
(CLOSE TO PANIC) No! No, Rachel, not that way! It’s coming from down there, it’s... no, wait, it’s behind us! It’s all around us, I can’t tell—
There! By the steps, just taking shape. Can you see it?
FX: TARDIS FULLY MATERIALISED
It’s them, they’ve come for us! I knew they would.
You have to get out of sight. We can’t let them see you here. Down there, Sam. Between those fighters. Go! I can handle them.
FX: SAM RUNS OFF. TARDIS DOORS OPEN
(IN MID-CONVERSATION) —saying is that we could be doing far more than we currently are to identify potential—
You there! Who are you?
Nope, sorry. Not how it works. You’re the one who set off the intruder alarm. So, you get to do the introductions first.
(AMUSED) Very well. I am Oberst Klein, in charge of Temporal Affairs for the Galactic Reich. You have heard of our department, I trust?
Ah. Yes. Sorry, ma’am. Rachel Cooper. I’m a member of the Ground Crew here. A technician. But—
This is the Moonbase?
That’s right, sir. Hangar Fourteen. You’ve missed the ramp by, oh, about fifteen metres.
And the year, Citizen Cooper? It is 2044, yes?

The one hundredth year of our Golden Age. Where else do you think we would be, Major Richter? Look at those ships! The first to be fitted with Dalek propulsion units. Those ships will expand our Empire beyond this one solar system. They will carry our colours to the stars and beyond.
I just wanted to be sure we were in the right—
When you’ve travelled as widely as I have, you develop an instinct about such things. Everything is as it should be.
Er.. yeah, now about that alarm? You know there’1l be a security detail on its way over here? I could call—
Good. Then they can inform your Commandant that we have arrived. (WALKING AWAY) And they can take my TARDIS to the Operations Centre.
(FX: KLEIN AND RICHTER MARCH AWAY; HEAVY DOORS SLIDE OPEN WITH A
Yes, ma’am. (TO SELF) No, ma’am. Three bags full, ma’am. So, that was the infamous Elizabeth Klein...
SCENE 2. MOONBASE RAMP
(FX: LOTS OF PEOPLE, ACTIVITY, ENGINE NOISES. STAY WITH KLEIN AND
AS THEY WALK)
That security detail should have been here to greet us. There is no excuse for complacency.
(WEARILY) I agree, Major Richter. But you and I might accept our fair share of the blame for that.
I assume that speech back there was for my benefit, ma’am. All that talk of our glorious Reich. I have not heard such passion from you in a long time.
I think it is important, sometimes, to reflect on all we have achieved. Without us—
Without us, Man could not live and work on the surface of the moon. He could not gaze up at the Earth, because there would be no eco-bubble to protect him.
Without us, those ships would be painted in the colours of our enemies. You and I remember this place as it was. But we are the only ones who do — and maybe that’s the problem.
FX: THEY HALT
Begging your pardon, ma’am, that is not the way to Generalleutnant Tendexter’s office.
You can deal with the Commandant. I have business to attend to.
The prisoner. I guessed as much when you brought us to this year again. Is he the reason you seem so... cautious, these days? We have achieved so much, Oberst Klein, but we can do more.
I’m aware of your feelings on that subject, Major Richter. But one day, you will understand. One day, when you have seen as many versions of this place as I have seen.
FX: KLEIN WALKS AWAY
(CALLS AFTER HER) Who is he, Klein? How is it that a mere prisoner has so much of a hold over you? (GIVES UP, TO SELF) Why do you keep bringing us back here?
SCENE 3. PRISON CELL
(FX: WATER DRIPPING. THUNK OF HEAVY LOCKS. IRON DOOR SCREECHES OPEN)
You’re back, then.
Yes, Doctor. I’m back.
OPENING THEME MUSIC
SCENE 4. HANGAR
It’s OK, Sam. They’ve gone now.
FX: SCRAPE AS SAM EMERGES FROM HIDING
(RATTLED) I thought they’d never go away. I thought they’d never get that box, that machine, out of here. What time is it? I’m due back on shift at twelve-hundred hours.
You’ve got time, Sam. It’s OK, you’ve got time.

What if they come back? What if they’re watching us now? What was I thinking? I have my cleaning job. I’m one of the lucky ones. So what if other people have more, if they were born with better genes than I was?
Don’t talk like that.
You saw what just happened, Rachel. Temporal Affairs, they were right here, and I can’t afford to—
They don’t know a thing. It was chance that brought Klein here, that’s all. Stupid, random chance.
I must have been mad. We must both have been mad. Nobody gets away with... something like this, with what you’re suggesting. When was the last time? When was the last time you heard of anyone—?
Because no one has tried.

People have tried, they just don’t.. We don’t remember it. You know that. You know how it works, what they can do. You heard how they came for Gustav two weeks ago, and Marc a few weeks before that. They can’t lose, Rachel.
Believe me, Sam, I know what I’m asking of you. If I could do this alone, I would. But I need you. And you came to me, remember.
Even if they don’t suspect us now, they will. They’1ll have time later, all the time in the world, to work it out, and then—
No. Don’t you see? If they were going to do that — if they were ever going to find out about us — they’d have come for us already. We’re safe. We’re the ones who can’t lose.
I’m sorry, I just can’t.. I can’t risk it. I’m a loyal citizen. Loyal to the Reich. Please, Rachel, just... just leave me alone!
FX: HE RUNS AWAY
Sam, no!
SCENE 5. TENDEXTER’S OFFICE
FX: PAPERS BEING LEAFED THROUGH
I’m sure you’ll find the paperwork in order, sir.
I don’t doubt it, Major Richter. One thing I will say for Temporal Affairs is that your paperwork is always immaculate.
FX: SHUFFLES THROUGH PAPERS
Thank you, sir.
Even if your commandant is apparently too preoccupied to present it to me in person.
Oberst Klein sends her apologies, but she had to—
I think I can guess where Oberst Klein is. My concern is that this will be — what? — the fourth member of my staff she has taken this year. If she is so keen to see my prisoner, she could just ask.
If you’d care to examine the seal on that warrant, Sit...
Yes, thank you, Major, I had made that observation.
Then you can appreciate that this is no trivial matter. This cleaner’s actions could undermine the security of the Reich itself.
And there has been a trial, I see. Or rather, there will be. Or will have been? A trial over which, it appears, I presided myself. Except that, of course, I have no memory of so doing.
The intentions of the accused are beyond doubt, sir. If we don’t act now, this crime will be committed. This base will be compromised.
(SIGHS) All right, Major Richter, I don’t need to hear the whole speech again. You may make your arrest. Take all the men you need to assist you.
Thank you, sir.
Well, I can hardly object, can I? I can hardly stand in your way. Not when it appears that I issued these papers myself.
SCENE 6. PRISON CELL
FX: CLINK OF CHAINS, WATER DRIPPING
I have to say, I’m impressed. Disappointed, but impressed. I had thought our interrogators might have softened your resolve by now.
Then perhaps your interrogators aren’t as good as you thought they were, Oberst Klein. Or perhaps I have already told them the truth.

I doubt that. You forget that I know you, Doctor. Oh, I know you don’t recall the adventures we had. You think we met for the first time in this squalid little cell, only a few months ago. But in another timeline, another world, we travelled in the TARDIS together.
I think you might have me confused with somebody else. Alone this time, I see?
A suicide mission? A clumsy attempt to sabotage our reactor core? Oh no, no, Doctor, I don’t think so.
You have no idea where I came from, this version of me. You think I might have a TARDIS of my own, somewhere on this base. And that worries you, doesn’t it?
You wouldn’t have come here without an escape route planned.
It worries you, because this power you think you wield — it’s worth nothing to you if you don’t wield it alone.
You know I’m keeping you alive, don’t you? Were it not for me, Tendexter would have had you executed long ago. If you could just open your eyes, if you could see what I’m building here.
I can see what you’ve torn down, Klein. You’ve rewritten history again and again until you like what you read.
And, of course, you would never do such a thing. If it weren’t for you, Doctor, my timeline — the proper timeline — would still be intact.
A
I’1ll have to take your word for that.
You just won’t accept it, will you? The year is 2044, and a unified Earth government has ended famine and disease, averted wars before they could even begin, repelled invaders from a score of worlds.

I can see how it happened, of course. You set out with one goal alone: to restore the timeline from which you came. But my TARDIS wouldn’t let you meet yourself, wouldn’t let you correct the mistake you once made.
I have used my TARDIS in ways you would never have dared dream. I have become the architect of a better world. A Golden Age.
And now, you’re exporting your idea of perfection to the stars. In swastika-patterned spaceships. I thought I was getting through to you, Klein. The last time you were here, with Faber, you seemed—
(RATTLED) Who... who are you talking about? Faber? I don’t know anyone called Faber.

Don’t you? The love of your life? The man you left behind in 1965? Think, Klein. I know it must be hard, sometimes, to know what’s real and what only used to be. Your head, filled with memories of days that never were.
You never met Faber. And I.. I never told you about him. Not this version of you. How could you...?

You’ve been travelling in time long enough now, Klein. Long enough to begin to see how its fragile strands are spun. Punch through them as you have been doing, and you risk bringing the whole web down.

You would say anything, do anything, to get your own way. But you had your chance, Doctor. You’ve had your time. It’s over. I don’t think you do have a plan, after all — else why would you have spent six months in chains?
What’s the point in escaping? You’d only go back in time and stop me, and I wouldn’t even remember it.
ile

So, to answer one of your questions: no, Doctor, you don’t worry me. But I will grant you this much: This is not the world, the timeline, I set out to restore all those years ago. It is a better one by far.
SCENE 7. REFECTORY
(FX: SMALL CROWD, CLINKING OF CUTLERY. DOOR CRASHES OPEN, SOLDIERS
IN, HALT)
I will have silence, please. (FX: ACTIVITY BEGINS TO SUBSIDE) (YELLS) Silence! (FX: ACTIVITY CEASES) You! Where do you think you're going?
I was taking these plates to the kitchen, sir. My duties—
I commend you on your diligence, Citizen. But I’m sure you would not wish me to think you were sneaking away, that you had something to hide?
No. No, sir. Nothing to hide. I am loyal to the Reich, I swear. And I always will be. In the future, I mean.
In the future. Of course. (TO ALL) Major Richter, Temporal Affairs. (FX: DISCONCERTED MURMURS) I am here to execute an arrest warrant. As, it seems, one among you has deduced already.
No, sir. I mean, yes sir. I mean, I’ve never seen you before. But your uniform insignia, that blue flash...

(TO ALL) You all know the principles upon which our society is built. We must stand united against the outsiders that would divide and destroy us. Sadly, some of us lack the strength of will to maintain that unity. Our intentions may be good, but our genes are weak. I want you to search your hearts, Citizens. Search your hearts, and be honest about what you find there - because, as your comrade here has so rightly surmised, I have seen the future. And I know that somebody in this room will betray us.
FX: MURMURS GROW, SHOCKED, PAPERS RUSTLE
I.. I don’t understand. Why are you giving me this...?
(SARCASTICALLY) Because you are a good and loyal Citizen. So, I know I can trust you to read out the name on these papers — and identify the traitor in question to me.
SCENE 8. OPERATIONS CENTRE
(FX: ABOUT TWENTY PEOPLE PRESENT, SOME ACTIVITY. MACHINERY HUMS AND CLICKS, RADAR PINGS. DOORS OPEN AND FOOTSTEPS )
All right, Feldwebel, I’m here. What’s the problem?
The tactical screen, sir. Those signatures. A moment ago, they weren’t there, I swear. I just don’t see how—
Let me see that... No. That can’t be. It’s impossible. It must be a malfunction. Didn’t you think to run a diagnostic before you disturbed me?
I did that, sir. The computer confirms it. There are six ships out there. Less than two light minutes away, and closing fast.
Then they’re already in... (FX: FRANTIC PRESSING OF SWITCHES) Why weren’t we warned? What’s the point of having a network of satellites if they don’t..? Didn’t we get a warning from the satellites?
Nothing, sir. As I said, the ships appeared from nowhere.
Diagnostic. Sensor systems functioning normally. Satellite network online and reporting no problems. End diagnostic.
I could try to contact them.

Yes. No. I want our fighters scrambled. ‘A’ Flight. I want visual confirmation. And I want to know how this happened. Our satellites.. Nothing should be able to enter this solar system without our knowing about it.
Should we put the Moonbase on alert, sir?
Yes. Yes, do that. And Klein! Her time machine is still here, she must be on the base. Get me Oberst Klein. At once.
FX: ALARM SIREN
Announcement. This installation is now on full alert. All operational personnel are to report to emergency positions. Repeat, this installation is now on full alert. End announcement.
Ai
SCENE 9. CORRIDOR
FX: SIREN CONTINUES, IN BACKGROUND
What made you change your mind?
That major. Klein’s stunted sidekick. He was in the refectory. I thought... His eyes were boring right through me. But it wasn’t me he wanted. It was Karen... Karen Montoya. She was so scared.
I don’t think I know her.

She just transferred from the Twilight Shift. Keeps herself to herself, works hard, but always seemed unhappy. She wanted to start a family, but she couldn’t get a permit. Maybe she just... I mean, one day she might have...
What did they do?
Marched her out of there. Told us to forget we ever knew her. Left us afraid to think the wrong thoughts. The same as they always do.
We can stop this, Sam. We can stop this today. But we have to act fast. Here.
What... what is this thing? It looks like a.. listening device.
It’s probably best if I don’t explain. But I need you to plant this on the TARDIS... on Klein’s time machine. It’1ll be in Operations. I don’t have the clearance to get in there, but you...
I’m rostered on there this afternoon. You mean...? I didn’t expect it to be so soon. Rachel...

I know, Sam, and I’m sorry. But you hear that siren? We’re out of time. If only I could see the future myself. If I’d known this morning that Klein and Richter were going to appear right in front of me...
No. No, it’s OK. In fact, it’s better this way. Because I’ve made up my mind, and that means... Well, the sooner, the better. Get it over with. Until we do, I’1ll always be waiting...
You just place that device on the time machine, Sam. That’s all
you have to do. But you have to do it this afternoon. It has to be now.
SCENE 10. OPERATIONS CENTRE
FX: SIREN HAS STOPPED. ATMOS AS BEFORE
You should have told me about this, Tendexter. Why didn’t I know about this?
I don’t know what you mean, Oberst Klein. I sent for you as soon as I-
I mean, the last time we met. Four years from now.
You think I’d keep something like this from you? Six unidentified craft within striking distance of Earth... This is exactly the sort of thing your department exists to prevent.
Indeed. And yet, we did not know this was coming. There was no report.
Well... then, maybe it will turn out to be nothing after all. An equipment malfunction, as I first thought. We’1ll soon know. I’ve scrambled eight fighters. They should be nearing—
Just eight?
We had twelve on standby, of course, but four of them.. Some manner of blockage at Hangar Fourteen. We’ve sounded the alert. Every ship on this base will be battle ready within six minutes.
Excuse me a moment. (FX: A COUPLE OF STEPS) Citizen Kirke, is it not?
Yes, sir. Sam Kirke, sir. I.. I clean in here three times a week. I could come back later, if you’d rather?
No, no, you go about your business. (SUSPICIOUS) You must have your Commandant’s trust, after all, to be working in his Operations Centre.
We’re getting pictures, sir, from Eagle One-Niner. Putting them on screen.
FX: CONTROLS
And there is the first of our enemy ships. Recognise the design, Major Richter?
It’s so... so black. That fin on its back, and that decal on its front. Like teeth. It looks like a...
A shark, Generalleutnant Tendexter. It looks like a shark.
So, this is an attack. But how is that possible? How could they have...? And why didn’t you see it? In the future?
All very good questions, Tendexter. And I suspect that only one man knows the answers. (FX: WALKING AWAY) Major Richter, you will prepare the TARDIS for departure. I will join you shortly.
SCENE 11. PRISON CELL
FX: IRON DOOR SCREECHES OPEN
Back so soon, Klein? I would offer you a cup of tea, perhaps a chocolate hobnob, but as you can see...
FX: DOCTOR’S CHAINS RATTLE
I’m not here to make small talk with you, Doctor.
What a shame. I thought we could reminisce again, about old times that never happened.
Not this time. This time, I want to talk about the Selachians.
Selachians?

Don’t play the innocent with me. In their time, the Selachians were the scourge of their galaxy. It took me months, and many trips in the TARDIS, to keep them from conquering this one too. But this is 2044 — and in 2044, the Selachians had not yet built their armoured suits, let alone developed space travel. So tell me, Doctor... what did you do?
SCENE 12. OPERATIONS CENTRE
FX: TARDIS EXTERNAL DOOR IS OPENED
Major Richter, you can’t just leave.
You heard Oberst Klein. I have to prepare the TARDIS for—
Please, can’t you help us? Those creatures... If they’re from the future, you must know something—
Selachians, Generalleutnant. They’re called Selachians. Walking, armoured sharks. Ruthless, paranoid and totally without pity.
But... but why are they here? What do they want? Maybe, if we knew that, we could negotiate with them.
What the Selachians want, sir, is to destroy you. You can attempt to negotiate with them if you wish. I wouldn’t give you much for your chances.
It’s the aliens, sir. They’re acknowledging our transmission.

Take that call. Put it on the screen here. No, belay that. Major Richter, you know these creatures, perhaps you could— Richter! (FX: TARDIS DOOR SLAMS) (SIGHS) All right, you just hide in your little blue box while I.. (TO FELDWEBEL) I’11l talk to them now. To the aliens.
Patching them through, sir.
FX: CONTROLS, QUICK HISS OF COMMUNICATIONS STATIC
I am Generalleutnant Adolph Tendexter, representing the Terran Galactic Reich. Your ships have violated our space, and I insist—

(FX: OVER RADIO) I do not care about your name or your rank. You are nothing but plankton to be ground beneath the heel of the Selachian Empire. Your primitive ships are no match for our warcraft. You have ten minutes to surrender — or else we will destroy you.
SCENE 13. CORRIDOR
FX: SAM RUNS UP
(CALLS) Rachel! Rachel!
Sam! You’re supposed to be in Operations.
Everyone was so busy. I slipped away. I had to find you, had to talk.
Did you do it, Sam? Did you plant the device on Klein’s TARDIS?
I think so. But Richter was there. He almost saw me. I didn’t have time to make sure it had stuck, but I think it did. Rachel, there are ships out there. Outsiders!
(TO SELF) It has to work. We can’t have gone through all this for nothing.
Did you hear what I said? The Moonbase, it’s under attack! And Klein... What if Klein was the only hope we had? What if we’ve.. What if we need her, after all? Maybe we should—
No, Sam. You did the right thing. I wish I had time to explain it to you, but we.. It’s best if we aren’t seen together.
FX: SHE STARTS TO MOVE AWAY, STOPS
I never thought this would be me, you know. Before we met. I never thought I’d be a rebel. I knew my place. I did as I was told.

I.. I was the opposite. I used to dream that Temporal Affairs would come for me, and I’d have to go on the run and join a resistance group. And then, one day, it was my twenty-first birthday, and I realised something. I realised they weren’t coming. I was never going to be important, never going to make a difference.
Thank you, Rachel. Whatever comes of this.. Thank you, for showing me who I can be.
What... what will you do? Where will you go?

Back to my old life. Back to my work, my cleaning. They won’t have missed me yet. And if they have... I’11 tell them I was afraid, that I ran. They won’t execute me for that. It’ll just be a few weeks in confinement.
I shouldn’t do this. I’m supposed to leave you behind, that was the plan, but I can’t just.. Come on, Sam. Quick, before I come to my senses!
FX: SHE DRAGS HIM OFF
What...? What are you..? Where are you going?
(CALLS) You’re coming with me, Sam Kirke! Come on!
SCENE 14. PRISON CELL
Don’t lie to me, Doctor. I see your hand in this. Or... or that of your people. I demand to know the truth!
You claim to know me, Klein. Then you ought to know how I respond to demands.
Why are the Selachians here? In this time period?
I really have no idea. But surely your Galactic Reich can defend itself against a few little monsters?
Of course it can. Our defences are decades ahead of their time. Our fighter ships are equipped with the finest weaponry of three galaxies.

And should they fail, you’1l just rub out the history books again. Start over. Only you can never quite get it right, can you? There’s always something more to be fixed, some new threat to counter. They just can’t seem to get along without your help.
That... that has been a concern of mine. But that’s why others have been trained to continue my work. So long as we have the TARDIS—
Others such as Faber. Whatever happened to him, Klein? Faber was important to you once. More important than any of this. You were a different person with him.
(RATTLED) This.. this is serious, Doctor. The Selachians have time travel.
So, what’s to stop them from doing to you what you did to them? What you’ve been doing to the rest of the universe?

(PULLS HERSELF TOGETHER) Very well then, keep your silence. I’m leaving now. I will see for myself the outcome of this attack, and I will learn how best to pre-empt it. When next we meet, you will have no memory of this conversation. But I will take great pleasure in explaining to you just how your oh-so-clever scheme has been thwarted.
FX: SHE MARCHES OUT, SLAMMING THE HEAVY DOOR BEHIND HER
(TO SELF) So, another strand breaks.
SCENE 15. OPERATIONS CENTRE
FX: DOOR OPENS AND FOOTSTEPS AS KLEIN ENTERS THE ROOM
Oberst Klein, thank goodness you’re back. The Selachians—
(BRUSQUELY, MARCHING PAST HIM) Put it in your report, Generalleutnant Tendexter. If you survive to file one. I’1ll read it in the future.
You can’t leave us now, we need you! We... we don’t know what to do. You’re supposed to tell us what to do.

(SIGHS) Must we go through this again? It’s always the same. Against the Sontarans, against the Daleks... If I had a hundred marks for every time I’ve seen you, or somebody like you, break under the pressure...
I don’t know what you mean. I was decorated for my part in the Dalek War.

In this timeline, perhaps so. This timeline, in which I was here to warn you of your mistakes, one by one, before you could make them. Don’t crow to me about your war record, Generalleutnant. The man standing in front of me now has never fought a war that wasn’t already won.
And I suppose this — we — are just one more mistake to you? One more of your ‘timelines’ to abandon as you please? Well, I won’t have it, Klein. As your superior officer, I am ordering you to—
You can’t order me to do anything, Tendexter. Where matters of the future are concerned, my department has jurisdiction. Continue to stand in my way, and I will have you charged with treason.
But what about us? What happens to us if you alter the past? Do we just.. just cease to exist? How will that happen? What will it feel like?

I don’t know, and I care less. But think of it this way. Perhaps will reach the future to learn that you dealt with this incident all by yourself, that my assistance was not required. Somehow, though, I doubt it. (FX: TARDIS DOOR OPENS) Goodbye, Generalleutnant Tendexter. I would wish you good luck — but frankly, it doesn’t matter a jot what you do now.
FX: TARDIS DOOR CLOSES
Damn you, Klein, you can’t do this to us. (FX: BANGS ON TARDIS) Come out of that box. I order you to come out of that box!
SCENE 16. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM
(FX: THE INTERIOR DOORS CLOSE AND FOOTSTEPS AS KLEIN WALKS TO THE CONSOLE. USUAL HUM, CONTROLS. NB — THIS IS THE TV MOVIE VERSION OF THE TARDIS INTERIOR)
I have set the coordinates, Oberst Klein. Central Records in Berlin, 2144. If you would like to confirm...?
(WEARILY) Just take us away from here, Richter. I will be in my quarters.
(FX: SHE LEAVES. MORE CONTROLS. TARDIS BEGINS TO DEMATERIALISE, BUT THE SOUND BECOMES STRAINED, JUDDERY )
(CALLS, WORRIED) Oberst? (LOUDER) Oberst Klein, there is something wrong here. These readings... Oberst Klein!
FX: KLEIN HURRIES BACK
Stand aside, let me see. I.. I don’t know what this means.
I performed the takeoff sequence as I always do. I didn’t make a mistake, I swear it. This can’t be my fault! (FX: CLOISTER BELL) That bell! Do you hear that bell? What does it mean?

The instruments are going haywire. The coordinates... They’re shifting back and forth, as if.. as if something is holding us here, anchoring us in this time. (FX: CONTROLS) Increase the power to the engines, Richter. That switch there. We’re going to drag ourselves free of—
(FX: SMALL EXPLOSIONS, ENGINE NOISES INCREASE IN PITCH AND INTENSITY. KLEIN AND RICHTER CRY OUT IN SURPRISE)
(CRIES) What’s happening, Klein?!
(CRIES) Shut it down! Shut it all down! Now!
(CRIES) It’s too late. We’re being torn apart!
(FX: THE ENGINES CONTINUE TO SCREECH AND GROAN ACCOMPANIED BY A SERIES OF EXPLOSIONS )
PART ONE

parts.searchable_dialogue:
COMPUTER VOICE: Warning. Incursion detected in Hangar Fourteen. End warning.
COMPUTER VOICE: (FX: SAM AND RACHEL RUN TOWARDS US, FOOTSTEPS RINGING ON STONE, STOP)
SAM: (CLOSE TO PANIC) No! No, Rachel, not that way! It’s coming from down there, it’s... no, wait, it’s behind us! It’s all around us, I can’t tell—
RACHEL: There! By the steps, just taking shape. Can you see it?
SAM: It’s them, they’ve come for us! I knew they would.
RACHEL: You have to get out of sight. We can’t let them see you here. Down there, Sam. Between those fighters. Go! I can handle them.
RICHTER: (IN MID-CONVERSATION) —saying is that we could be doing far more than we currently are to identify potential—
KLEIN: You there! Who are you?
RACHEL: Nope, sorry. Not how it works. You’re the one who set off the intruder alarm. So, you get to do the introductions first.
KLEIN: (AMUSED) Very well. I am Oberst Klein, in charge of Temporal Affairs for the Galactic Reich. You have heard of our department, I trust?
RACHEL: Ah. Yes. Sorry, ma’am. Rachel Cooper. I’m a member of the Ground Crew here. A technician. But—
RICHTER: This is the Moonbase?
RACHEL: That’s right, sir. Hangar Fourteen. You’ve missed the ramp by, oh, about fifteen metres.

DOCTOR: Why, thank you, Klein.
KLEIN: (TO ALL) Look at this man, all of you. This man could save our lives, but he chooses not to. It’s against his principles! (FX:
UNCERTAIN: MURMURS FROM TWENTY OR SO PEOPLE) (TO DOCTOR) Well, good for you, Doctor. Now, at least you can die with a smug look on your face.
DOCTOR: Alternatively, I could live. We could all live. Everybody on this base, both inside this room and outside of it. There might be a way.
TENDEXTER: ‘Might be’?
DOCTOR: I think I know what’s going on now. I think I can stop the
DOCTOR: killing. But it’s something of a gamble. If I’m wrong...
TENDEXTER: What makes me think I’m not going to like this?
TENDEXTER: 52
TENDEXTER: SCENE 30. HANGAR/FIGHTER COCKPIT
SAM: (HUSHED) What’s happening? Rachel? I think we should get down from here.
RACHEL: (HUSHED) A few more seconds. If I can just get power to the cockpit systems... (FX: HITS DASHBOARD) Blast it!
SAM: I can’t see the Selachian. It could be sneaking up behind us. Rachel...
RACHEL: I doubt it. That armour isn’t made for sneaking. Pass me that wrench, would you, Sam?
SAM: This fighter wouldn’t even be here if.. I mean, this is a maintenance hangar. And even if we could... Once you get the engines running, how are we supposed to get the Selachian standing by the intake valves?
RACHEL: (DISTRACTED) One worry at a time. If only the Doctor were here, he'd have a plan. He always had a plan. He didn’t always tell me what the plan was...
SAM: You really think he could beat the Selachians?
RACHEL: He’s done it before. Selachians, Sontarans, Autons. But this time... This time, even he seemed... He said that, this time — and this is ridiculous, because the last time we fought the Daleks, they were threatening the universe — this time, he said the stakes were the highest they’d ever been.
SAM: Rachel, I...
RACHEL: (STILL DISTRACTED) So, he takes me back to Earth. He plonks me right back down in my old life, working in the garage. Only he’s fixed it so that, a few days later, I get my call-up papers.
SAM: Rachel, I think there... There’s something I should tell you.
SAM: 53
RACHEL: So, a week after that, I’m working on the Moonbase, and the Doctor — he’s already here, a prisoner. And he’s left me a list of instructions, but nothing about what to do when (GRUNTS WITH EFFORT) (FX: METALLIC THUNK) when things go wrong.
SAM: The Selachians... (CRIES) Rachel, the Selachian! It’s found us! Jump, Rachel! Jump for it!
RACHEL: (CRIES) Sam!
RACHEL: 54
RACHEL: SCENE 31. OPERATIONS CENTRE
RACHEL: (FX: MUFFLED CONCENTRATED GUNFIRE THEN AN EXPLOSION AS THE DOORS
ARE: BLOWN OPEN. FOUR SELACHIANS STOMP IN)
SELACHTIAN LEADER: Do not move. You are prisoners of the Selachian Empire.
TENDEXTER: Selachian Leader, hear me. I am Generalleutnant Adolph Tendexter, and I-—
SELACHTIAN LEADER: We have been introduced. Troopers, kill everyone in this room!
SELACHTIAN LEADER: (FX: THE SELACHIAN WEAPONS ARE COCKED AND CHARGED TO FIRE. SHOCKED REACTION)
TENDEXTER: No, wait! We.. we’re doing what you wanted. We’ve put down our guns. I’ve called off the attack on your ships. We’re surrendering to you!
DOCTOR: Stand down your troopers, Leader. That’s an order. There will be no more deaths today.
SELACHTIAN LEADER: And who are you, human, to give me orders? I am in command here! This Moonbase belongs to the Selachians!
DOCTOR: Look more closely, Leader. I am not human. And you have achieved your objectives. The Reich’s time machine is destroyed; its former pilot is your prisoner. There she is, standing in front of you.
KLEIN: What... what are you saying? You’re betraying me to them?
TENDEXTER: Doctor, what is the meaning of this? You said you could—
SELACHIAN LEADER: ‘Doctor’? I have heard that name.
DOCTOR: That’s right, you have. I’m the reason you’re here. I gave your rulers the means to reach this Moonbase, a hundred years into their own past — and I told them how to conquer it. I planned this invasion, right down to the last detail. And that, Leader, is why I am now taking command.
END: PART TWO
END: 55

elements.text: PART THREE
Stand down your troopers, Leader. That’s an order. There will be no more deaths today.
And who are you, human, to give me orders? I am in command here! This Moonbase belongs to the Selachians!
Look more closely, Leader. I am not human. And you have achieved your objectives. The Reich’s time machine is destroyed; its former pilot is your prisoner. There she is, standing in front of you.
What... what are you saying? You’re betraying me to them?
Doctor, what is the meaning of this? You said you could—
‘Doctor’? I have heard that name.

That’s right, you have. I’m the reason you’re here. I gave your rulers the means to reach this Moonbase, a hundred years into their own past — and I told them how to conquer it. I planned this invasion, right down to the last detail. And that, Leader, is why I am now taking command.
SCENE 31 (cont).
(FX: SLOW HAND CLAP) Oh, well played, Doctor. You certainly had me fooled. You have a ruthless streak in you, after all.
The prisoner will remain silent! Leader, you will take these humans to the detention block. Tendexter can show you the way. But ensure that Klein has a cell to herself. I haven’t finished with her.
Tendexter stays here.
That was not a request, Leader.
The woman, Klein, is yours. That was your agreement with our Supreme Leader. But this human is mine. I have questions to put to him.
Oh, very well. But remember what I told you. No more deaths.
I cannot promise that. The humans will be treated according to their actions. Any attempt to defy us, any failure to follow Selachian instructions, and their lives will be forfeit.
SCENE 32. HANGAR
(FX: GUN BLAST OF SELACHIAN WEAPON AND RUNNING FEET OF RACHEL AND SAM)
You cannot run forever, plankton.
The rivet gun, Sam. Well, don’t just stand there, use it! Shoot! Here, give me that thing!
(FX: SELACHIAN STOMPS CLOSER, FIRING. REPEATED FIRING OF RIVET GUN, RIVETS PING OFF ARMOUR)
It’s no use, Rachel. You’re not making a dent!
No, look! It’s left arm. Do you see that? That crack? It’s just a hairline fracture, but—
It must have been Richter. He must have damaged it before he...
(FX: ANOTHER BURST FROM RIVET GUN, THEN DRY CLICKS, SELACHIAN CLOSING)
Damn it, I’m out of ammo! I need something else. Sam!
FX: SELACHIAN FIRES AGAIN. METAL OBJECT WRENCHED FROM BRACKETS
How about a fire extinguisher?
You have nowhere left to run. Now, you will die. Accept your— (FX:
BURSTS FROM FIRE EXTINGUISHER) (A HOWL OF ANGER AND CONFUSION)
Sam, that... that’s brilliant! That’s right, keep aiming for its eyes. If you can cover the helmet with foam, I can— (GRUNTS WITH
(FX: SCRAPE OF METAL, RACHEL CHARGES SELACHIAN AND ATTACKS IT WITH A WRENCH)
CRIES OUT
Rachel! Watch out for its arm!
(SIMULTANEOUSLY — A CRY OF SURPRISE AND PAIN) (FX: SELACHIAN
ABOUT, DISORIENTED, WATER DRAINING OUT FROM THE FRACTURE.
RUNS TO RACHEL) (WINDED) Winded me. I can’t... can’t...
You did it, Rachel. You widened the fracture. There... there’s water coming out of its armour. But it’s still on its feet. Lean on me, come on. We have to move.
For this, you will not die quickly. You will be dismembered, limb by limb.
(FX: SELACHIAN GUN FIRES THREE TIMES AS SAM AND RACHEL HOBBLE
It’s still standing. Rachel, it’s still standing!

(BREATHLESS) Give it time, Sam. It’s losing water, it can’t last much longer. (FX: THEY HALT) We just... just have to keep out of its reach until it drops. (FX: SELACHIAN BLAST, SAM AND RACHEL RUN AWAY FROM US) Which might be easier said than done. Run!
FX: STAY WITH SELACHIAN AS IT THRASHES ABOUT, ARMOUR CLANGING
DYING GURGLES
FX: SELACHIAN FALLS
SCENE 33. PRISON CELL
(FX: ATMOS AS IN SCENE 3. THUNK OF HEAVY LOCKS. IRON DOOR
OPEN)
And here he is, the all-conquering hero.
Enjoying your new accommodations, Klein? I would say I have fond memories of my time chained up in here, but that wouldn’t be quite true.
What do you want from me?
I only remember the last three days, as you know. I did grow to appreciate the subtlety of that water drip, however. Do you hear that?
I’m not deaf.

It’s artificial, of course. Intended to break the spirit of this cell’s occupant. A constant reminder to him — or to her — of the passing of time. Every minute, every second, every... (FX: DRIP) drip.
Have you come here just to gloat? You’ve got what you wanted, Doctor.
Don’t be so obtuse, Klein. I told you — I keep telling you — I’m not the Doctor you thought I was. I have no memory of this timeline of yours.

All the same, our positions have been quite neatly reversed, haven’t they? Now you’re the one prepared to sacrifice the rest of us, prepared to go to any lengths, to bring back your world. Because that’s what this is all about, isn’t it? Your alliance with those monsters...
I swear, I didn’t know.

How do you justify that to yourself? No, I can guess. Soon, this timeline will be erased. So, anyone who has suffered and died here for your sake — it won’t have happened any more. Your conscience will be clear.
What I said to the Selachian Leader, I couldn’t be sure any of it was true. I still don’t know the full extent of my alternative self’s plan — and I certainly don’t approve of it.
Don’t you? I have seen hundreds of possible worlds — and one thing I have learned is that people rarely change. The Doctor of this timeline.. If you had lived his life, seen what he has seen...
I refuse to believe that!
I think we’re finally seeing the real you. And the two of us, it appears, are a lot more alike than you would care to admit.
SCENE 34. OPERATIONS CENTRE
FX: NO BACKGROUND CHATTER, BUT INSTRUMENTS AS NORMAL
(A GURGLING GROWL OF ANGER) Tendexter, you have lied to me.
(DEFEATED) I haven’t, I swear. I’ve answered your questions.
You offered me your people’s surrender. Why is it, then, that I can no longer contact one of my troopers?
I don’t know. How could I know? You’ve kept me here in this room like some... some slave to do your bidding. Whatever has happened out there—
(ROARS) One of your treacherous kind has murdered one of mine.
And I’m supposed to be sorry about that? Why are you still here, anyway? You’ve destroyed our time machine. You’ve emptied our Vault of technology.
I will decide when our work here is done.
FX: A SELACHIAN MARCHES IN, WITH SIX VERY NERVOUS HUMANS
What... what’s happening now? What are these people doing back here?
I brought the prisoners as you instructed, Leader. Six of them.
I gave you fair warning, human. I told you what would happen if we were met with resistance.
No! No, you can’t mean to... Earth knows what’s happening up here, you know. I alerted them as soon as your ships appeared. They’11 be making plans.
The blood of my kind has been spilt, Tendexter. I will have the blood of yours in recompense. (TO THE SELACHIAN) Kill them.
(CRIES) No!
FX: SELACHIAN GUN FIRES REPEATEDLY, PEOPLE SCREAM AS THEY DIE
SCENE 35. HANGAR
FX: TINKERING
(BREATHLESS THROUGHOUT THIS SCENE) Are you certain it’s dead?
(SAME) If it wasn’t, I would be by now. I can’t imagine a live Selachian just lying here while I... (FX: WRENCH OF METAL) (GRUNTS WITH EFFORT) while I take its armour apart. (FX: HISSING —
BETWEEN SPARKING WIRES AND SNAKES) Oh, that’s charming, that is. That’s rank!
They look like... worms! Is that... is that the Selachian?
No, Sam. That, I hope, is the inside of a transmat module. Organic wiring, you see, grown rather than made. The Zygons have something Similar.
You talk about all this as if it’s normal. As if it’s something you see every day.

Yeah, well. It’s been a long time, actually. But you can’t imagine what it’s like, Sam, out there. You think you know what life is about, but there’s so much more, so much they’ve been keeping from us.
I know what you mean. They don’t want us to dream.
I’m going to show you the stars, Sam. Like the Doctor showed me. Once we get out of here...
If we get out of here. Can’t be much air left now. Can you make it work, the transmat?
I think so. The tricky part will be unwiring it from the armour. It looks like.. oh, gross! It looks like those worms feed off the Selachian’s blood.
(NAUSEATED) Maybe... maybe I’1l take another look round, see if I can’t find a pair of spacesuits after all.
FX: STAY WITH SAM AS HE WALKS AWAY

Yeah. Maybe you should. The pilots do leave their suits in the hangars sometimes. They’re not supposed to, but they do. And a quick space walk, that has to be better than... than trusting our component molecules to a bunch of... (FX: SQUELCH) (DISGUSTED) Oh, that’s not good!
(STAGE WHISPER) Rachel? Rachel, it’s Richter. Richter’s body. He was lying right here. But—
(CALLS FROM MID-DISTANCE) What was that, Sam?
(A LOUDER HISS) Major Richter! He’s gone! Disappeared!
FX: RICHTER STEPS OUT

Don’t worry, Citizen Kirke, I haven’t gone far. Fortunately, the body armour of the thirty-first century is every bit as good as its weaponry. Now, as I recall, we were interrupted in mid-‘witch hunt’...
SCENE 36. PRISON CELL
Tell me about him, Doctor. About Faber.
Are you sure? You didn’t want to know before.
You remember what I told you, of course. In your timeline. I thought you’d have forgotten. Was he really here?
You tell me. The man you loved and lost... And you with a ship that can take you anywhere in space and time. Why didn’t you go back for him?
I always thought, one day... one day, when my work was done. But somehow, I kept... I just kept putting it off. Maybe I was afraid that—
Or maybe you weren’t. Just how many people did you train in the use of my TARDIS, Klein?
You don’t mean... No. No, they couldn’t have.

When you rewrote history, you made yourself the most important person in it. A Lord of Time. Everyone was afraid of you, including the leaders you professed to serve. And what do you Suppose frightened them the most?
The Fihrer — every one I ever met — was afraid that my contact with outsiders would... change me, that I might turn against him.

Not a pleasant thought, is it? That your past itself might not be your own? That somebody else might have looked at your life, and decided that it needed a few small changes. To keep you in your place.
And... and what about your past? What would you like to change? I think we both know, now, why you came to this Moonbase. You wanted to lure me here. And you orchestrated the Selachians’ attack—
None of that was me! That was my other self. The Doctor who belongs in this timeline.
Nevertheless, I’m here. You’re here. They’re here. And you’re running out of options. So, tell me, Doctor, what next? Are you going to do it? Are you going to execute me?
You seem remarkably sanguine about that prospect.

I didn’t expect to feel.. almost relieved, I suppose. That it’s over. You were right about one thing, at least. No matter how many trips I took in the TARDIS, how much I changed, I could never quite make things right.
Of course you couldn’t. I could have told you that from the start, Klein. You could never go home.
AFTER A SHORT PAUSE, SHAKEN, TRYING TO PULL HERSELF TOGETHER
You.. you won’t do it. You won’t kill me. You’re too squeamish.

You're right. I won’t. Apart from anything else, it would achieve very little, now that you no longer have a time machine. I didn’t come here to execute you, Klein — no version of me did. What I came here to do, I’m beginning to suspect, was something far worse.
SCENE 37. OPERATIONS CENTRE/CORRIDOR
You will begin now, Tendexter.
You don’t have to do this. Why don’t we find the Doctor? Why don’t we talk to him before—?
You know what you have to say. My troopers are fetching six more prisoners as we speak. If you would rather exchange places with one of them...

No, I’1l do it. I.. I need a moment to collect my thoughts, that’s all. (FX: CONTROLS) (DEEP BREATH) Attention, all Moonbase personnel, this is your Command— This is Tendexter. I’ve been asked to speak to you, because... (FX: CUT TO CORRIDOR, SPEECH

OVER SPEAKER) something has happened. One of the Selachians, our occupiers, has been killed. And the Selachian Leader... the Selachian Leader and I would like the culprit to come forward. If he does, I have been promised that nobody else will be hurt. The Selachians will take what they want and they’1ll leave us be. Otherwise... They’ve already shot six people. Colleagues of ours. Friends. They say that, until the man who killed their trooper comes forward, there will be six more deaths every half- hour. I’m appealing to you, all of you, please... We can’t beat these monsters. It’s futile to even try.
(THE SPEECH CROSSFADES TO A TANNOY AT THE START OF THE FOLLOWING SCENE )
SCENE 38. HANGAR
(FX:WE HEAR THE LAST FEW WORDS OF THE ADDRESS AND THERE IS A
SQUEAL AS SPEAKER CUTS OUT, RACHEL TINKERING)
(STILL BREATHLESS) What... what do we do? You heard what the Commandant said. If we don’t turn ourselves in—
(SAME) It might be a moot point, Sam. I’ve got the transmat device unwired from the armour, but I can’t... Without Selachian blood to power it...
(SAME) If you can’t make that device work, Citizen Cooper, then the two of you are dead.
You mean the three of us, don’t you?
Can’t we at least contact the Selachians? Tell them it was us that killed their trooper, and that we... we’re dying anyway?
There’s a spacesuit next to the back wall. One person can walk out of here. Of course, the other two will die when he opens the door.
So, let me guess. We draw straws, right?

That would be one option. Another would be that the man with the gun gets the spacesuit. A pity, really. Citizen Kirke here will be no loss to anyone, but you.. I would have liked to have saved you, Citizen Cooper. I would have liked to have heard how that story of yours ends.
FX: GUN COCKS
What are you doing?

Don’t worry, I wouldn’t waste a charge cycle on shooting you. What would be the point? But I did think I might destroy that transmat device before I leave. Just in case you haven’t been entirely honest with me.
No, don’t! I.. OK, there might be a way we can all get out of here.
I’m listening.
When I said I couldn’t.. What I mean is, I can maybe get one journey out of this thing. The trouble is, it was designed for personal use. It can only take the weight of one Selachian.
But one Selachian in its armour must be as heavy as two people.
That’s right. Two. Not three. And the spacesuit would still be safer. Why don’t you take that, and Sam and I can—?

I don’t think so, Citizen Cooper. I would rather keep you within reach. We will transmat out of here together, while Citizen Kirke... well, I’m not sure I can allow a traitor to the Galactic Reich to walk free.
You kill him, Richter — you hurt Sam in any way — and I swear, I’ll short this thing out myself. Here, take this!
What are you—?
The Selachian’s gauntlet. Grab hold. One-time offer, Richter. Live or die. But you have to decide right now.

You’re bluffing, of course. You wouldn’t sacrifice yourself, wouldn’t jeopardise whatever plans you have made with your Doctor friend, for the sake of a cleaner. But very well, I will play your game. After all, what harm can it—? (FX: CRACKLE OF ELECTRICITY)
CRY OF PAIN
(CRIES) What did you do?
Take my hand, Sam. We’re getting out of here.
FX: CONTROLS, OUTGOING TRANSMAT
(WEAK, STRAINED) You won’t get away with this! (FX: GUNSHOT) I will track you down and I will kill you both, do you hear me? I
will kill you both!
FX: TWO MORE GUNSHOTS
SCENE 39. PRISON CELL
FX: HEAVY DOOR IS OPENED
Where are you going?
You heard Tendexter’s broadcast. There are people in danger. I’m going to help them.
You’re insane! The Selachians—
As it seems I brought them here, it’s up to me to deal with them.
Not this time, Doctor. You know what you’re supposed to do this time. You’ve already admitted—
You wouldn’t understand. You were wrong about me, Klein. What happens here, in this timeline, it does matter. Those people out there matter. I can’t let them suffer. I won’t.
Everything you said about the web of Time... about the damage I did to it, the broken strands... was any of that true?
Every word.

Then what right have you to walk out of here now? We’re talking about a handful of lives, weighed against the whole of space and time. And you’re willing to take that gamble, risk everything, to make a point?

It’s more than that. I’m not that man, Klein, the man you want me to be. You can say what you like, even rewrite my past, but it doesn’t change who I am. If I can save them, I will. I’m the Doctor. And that’s what I do.
SCENE 40. CORRIDOR
FX: IN MID-DISTANCE: CELL DOOR IS SLAMMED, LOCKED
(HUSHED) That’s him, Sam. That’s the Doctor! What’s he still doing here?
HUSHED; THROUGHOUT THIS SCENE, INCREASINGLY STRAINED, DISTANT
That’s the Doctor?
Do you think he saw us? He seemed to glance this way. If I could just speak to him. If that Selachian wasn’t standing guard over him...
It doesn’t look like it’s standing guard. It looks more like... (FX: DOCTOR AND SELACHIAN MOVE AWAY) like an escort to me. As if the Doctor’s the one giving the orders.
That’s the way to the Operations Centre. But, Sam, he was supposed to meet us. He was supposed to meet me. Outside Hangar Fourteen. And I thought... I think he was supposed to bring Klein with him.
You ‘think’?
Maybe... maybe, if he heard Tendexter’s broadcast... Yeah, that’1ll be it, he wouldn’t leave those people to die! But... what about us, Sam? What do we do? What if he needs our help?
We could make things worse by interfering. We should just do as the Doctor said, find a pair of spacesuits and—
It’s been six months since I spoke to him. He’s always been too well guarded. Six months! Anything could have happened in that time. What if things have changed? What if.. Sam! Sam, are you OK?
(WEAK) I’m OK. I just... I had a bit of a dizzy turn there.
Your shoulder... Oh God, why didn’t you tell me? You’ve been shot!
It’s OK, Rachel. Really, it’s OK. It’s just a flesh wound. Richter... As we transmatted out of the hangar—

Let me see. I said, let me see. Oh, Sam, you should have told me. I should have noticed, instead of blathering on about... That gun, Richter’s gun, it fired plasma bullets. They don’t just burn your skin, they burst inside your body. We have to get you some help.
No time. Too dangerous. Hangar Fourteen... If that’s where we’re going, I can hold on till we get there. I can... (GROANS)
(CRIES) Sam!
SCENE 41. OPERATIONS CENTRE
This is intolerable, Doctor. You have no right to interfere in—
I have every right, according to my agreement with your Supreme Leader. If you have a problem with that—
One of my troopers is dead. There must be consequences, else the surface dwellers will think us weak.
What did you expect? Your bombs slaughtered them in their hundreds. They’re always going to fight you.
You were not so squeamish when you planned that attack. You agreed that the destruction of the atmospheric bubble was the most efficient—
That was then. I said ‘no more deaths’, Leader, and I meant it.
You know what these humans did, what they will do to us in the future. I will not let that happen again. Those, Doctor, are my orders.
FX: SELACHIAN LEADER STOMPS OFF
Do you think... Did you get through to him? Will he stop the executions?

For now. The Selachians like to throw their weight around — but, beneath all that, they’re basically insecure. So long as our agreement stands, they won’t risk breaking it. I’m sure they know what I can do.
Is it true what he said? Is all this, what they’re doing here... Is it all just payback for what we’ll do to them some day?
I haven’t seen the future of your timeline, Tendexter. But if it’s anything like the one I have seen, the human race has a great deal to answer for.
Then it’s the same where you come from? Things are no better there?
I never said my world was perfect.
SCENE 42. CORRIDOR
FX: BIG AIRLOCK DOOR THUNKS OPEN
Halt! This base is under Selachian control. Access to other life forms is denied. Identify yourself!
(FX: THROUGH A TINY SPEAKER, DISTORTED, UNRECOGNISABLE) Don’t shoot. I’ve come to turn myself in. I have information for you.
I said, identify yourself. Remove the spacesuit helmet, and show me your face.

Very well. (FX: CLIPS UNDONE, HISS OF ESCAPING AIR) (NORMAL VOICE) Major Richter, Assistant Head of Temporal Affairs for the Galactic Reich. And if you’re interested, I can tell you who killed your comrade out there.
Tell me what you know.
In a moment. First, I have a question for you. Those guns your lot wear strapped to your arms — could they penetrate your own armour?
It is not for you to question Selachian technology.
I’ll find out for myself, then.
FX: RICHTER FIRES WITH SELACHIAN GUN
SCENE 43. PRISON CELL
FX: TWO SELACHIAN GUNS EXCHANGE FIRE, OUTSIDE, MUFFLED
(CALLS) Who’s there? What’s happening out there? (FX: FOOTSTEPS
DOOR) Doctor? Doctor, is that you?
FX: DOOR UNLOCKED, SCREECHES OPEN
No, Oberst Klein. It is not your outsider friend.
(SIGHS) Richter! I might have guessed. Where did you get the gun?
(FX: RICHTER CROSSES THE CELL IN A COUPLE OF PACES, UNLOCKS HER CHAINS)
I pulled it off the arm of a dead Selachian. There’s another one outside the door. But we need to move, before they—
Oh, no, no, no. I’m not going anywhere with you.
You don’t have any choice.
I believe I do. I believe the Doctor will come to his senses and return for me. In the meantime, this cell is the safest place for me to be.
So, you confess that you are working with him now.
I have... reached a decision, yes. And what about you, Richter? Who do you work for? You’ve always been ambitious. Enough so to have taken my TARDIS, behind my back? To have interfered in my past?
That’s ‘Major Richter’ to you. And I don’t know what you’re talking about. But I think you’ve misunderstood me, Klein. You have no choice but to come with me — because if you don’t, I will shoot you.
You’ve picked the wrong time to stage a mutiny, Major Richter. I have no ship for you to seize.

You know, I wasn’t just appointed to be your deputy. I pulled every string I could for the chance to work with you. I’d heard how efficient, how ruthless, you were. I could see from the start that something had changed. You were always just going through the motions.
Then leave me, Richter. Let me stay here! You don’t need me.
You’ve no idea how tempting that sounds. But you have more experience with time machines than I do.
